UseCaseTitle: AI-powered Network Incident Prediction and Resolution
Purpose: To proactively predict, diagnose, and resolve network outages in telecom and IT service operations using graph-based AI agents, reducing downtime and improving network reliability.
ExecSummary: Telecom and IT service providers face increasing complexity in managing network infrastructure with frequent outages causing significant operational disruptions and customer dissatisfaction. Traditional reactive approaches lead to longer downtimes and higher costs. This demo showcases an autonomous multi-agent system leveraging graph AI, contextual memory, and dynamic workflows to predict incidents early and enable automated troubleshooting.
ExecSummaryKeyAsks: Automate root cause analysis and resolution workflows
Improve network uptime and customer satisfaction
BusinessObjectives: Minimize network downtime and service impact
Support real-time incident visibility and reporting
BusinessBenefits: Improved SLA compliance and customer experience
overview: This demo implements an end-to-end Agentic AI framework designed for intelligent telecom network operations. It uses graph neural network models (via NetworkX and Neo4j) combined with multi-agent orchestration through LangGraph to autonomously handle complex incident prediction and troubleshooting tasks.
business: Network outages cause revenue loss and customer churn in telecom and IT service companies. Manual incident management is slow and error-prone. There is a growing need for AI-driven autonomous systems that leverage graph analytics and contextual knowledge to predict and resolve issues before they escalate.
approach: The solution integrates graph analytics for network topology and incident modeling, LangGraph for orchestrating multi-agent workflows, Faiss for semantic search of incident knowledge, and Neo4j as a contextual knowledge graph. Agents communicate indirectly via contextual memory to maintain modularity and traceability.
BusinessDrivers: Drive proactive network management to reduce outages
Automate incident workflows to reduce manual efforts
Scale operations without linear increases in manpower
BusinessChallanges: Fragmented knowledge across tools and teams
High operational costs due to manual troubleshooting
Difficulty in maintaining consistent incident resolutions
FunctionalOverview: Incident Prediction: Analyze network telemetry and topology graphs to forecast potential outages.
Root Cause Analysis: AI agents autonomously identify probable causes using graph-based reasoning.
Automated Troubleshooting: Execute resolution workflows via multi-agent collaboration.
Contextual Memory: Maintain state and history of incidents across agents and time.
Multi-channel Notifications: Provide real-time alerts and incident updates to stakeholders.

FunctionalComponentDetails.Description: Monitors network data streams and applies graph neural networks to predict potential failures before they impact services.

FunctionalComponentDetails.FunctionalComponentTitle: Root Cause Analysis and Troubleshooting Module
FunctionalComponentDetails.Description: Automatically identifies root causes of incidents using Neo4j knowledge graph and orchestrates multi-agent troubleshooting workflows with LangGraph.
KeyFeatures: Integration with existing network management tools

SolutionOverview: Graph Neural Network models for network anomaly detection
Multi-agent orchestration via LangGraph for autonomous workflows
Semantic search using Faiss-powered RAG on historical incident data
Contextual memory stored in Neo4j for knowledge persistence
Real-time incident alerting and status updates
dataflow: Network telemetry and topology data feed into the Incident Prediction Agent, which flags potential outages. Root Cause Analysis Agent queries Neo4j knowledge graph and triggers Troubleshooting Agent workflows. All agents share state via contextual memory. Notifications are sent to operators with resolution updates.
design: Each agent runs in isolated containers orchestrated by LangGraph, executing event-triggered state machines. Data integrations with telemetry and network management tools support real-time workflows. A supervisor agent monitors agent health and fallback mechanisms.

cost.CAPEX: 80,000 - includes design, agent development, infrastructure, and integration
cost.OPEX: 7,500/month - covers compute resources, monitoring, and support
